video.title: Learn HTML5 - full course with code samples
video.description:
This course is the quickest way to learn the basics of HTML. Watch it here on YouTube or check out the interactive version at Scrimba, where you'll be able to play with the code as well: https://scrimba.com/g/ghtml

HTML is one of the core building blocks on the web, as it's what holds the content on all the websites you visit. Thus, HTML is a must-have skill for all web developers. 

While HTML is a huge subject, the basics can be learned quickly. This course aims at taking you from absolute beginner to proficient in HTML in less than an hour. Throughout the lectures, you'll be building a neat-looking website from scratch together with the brilliant instructor Eric Tirado.

Get the 'index.css' file from this course here: https://gist.github.com/beaucarnes/ec37029de1b774d857c50828b5c837d9

What you'll learn in this web development html crash course:

- Intro to web architecture (0:00)
- HTML documents (4:25)
- Nesting (7:19)
- Head elements and scripts (11:23)
- Layout elements (17:33)
- Figure and image elements (20:28)
- Embedding videos (26:54)
- Navbar and list items (31:12)
- Headings (34:05)
- Text formatting (36:04)
- Tables (42:15)
- Links and final touches (49:27)

You can follow the creator on Twitter here:
https://twitter.com/iamtirado

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.com

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.com

topLevelComment.author: Diane Webb
topLevelComment.text: Doesn't work with Sublime Text. Something in your code is buggy for use with Sublime. It's like it doesn't even recognize you have a stylesheet. I came to see if I could grab some HTML tips I don't already know, but this is definitely not aimed at beginners. I would have quit coding if this was the beginner class I would have had, frustrating learners on a basic beginner course is the quickest way to make them feel like they can't learn code. Learners shouldn't have to try to diagnose issues in the code you are teaching them. If it only works in Scrimba, then direct people to that application only. I'd take a look at this video and the css you added in git and figure out why so many are having issues with this tutorial.

topLevelComment.author: Dominick Villegas
topLevelComment.text: Day 3 of becoming a web developer. I thoroughly completed another HTML basics video and have logged 8.5 hours of practice. Every hour goes by really fast! I also found myself spending my free time looking at cool websites, cool HTML, and writing down creative website ideas of my own that I will pursue after I learn the basics. Very fun!

replies.author: Shanks Yagami
replies.text: @Dominick Villegas Thank You for the advice appreciate it 🙏. My uncle also learned web development from W3S.

replies.author: Dominick Villegas
replies.text: @Shanks Yagami let me add that w3schools may still be challenging as a beginner and that’s totally fine. But it’s a first step to being able to read the language of web development, which is something you’ll engage with almost every day as a professional.

replies.author: Dominick Villegas
replies.text:
@Shanks Yagami  hey. Good luck on your journey.

Unfortunately, I can’t give you any recommendations for channels, but I’ll give you my general thoughts after reading your question.

For a good intro to front end web development, I can recommend Zero to Mastery on Udemy.

As far as websites go, I think w3schools is pretty beginner friendly. They do use technical terms, but they provide good examples that you can play with in a sandbox.

After you feel comfortable with a concept in w3schools, you might be ready to read the same concept in MDN.

Eventually, you want to be able to comfortably ready official documentation as this is the best source of info and allows you to become familiar with technical terms. You’ll find that a lot of YouTube videos take examples straight from official documentation.

In summary w3schools -> MDN -> official docs

If you have more questions feel free to reach out

replies.author: Dominick Villegas
replies.text:
@Chrisso  hey sorry I didn’t reply to you quicker.

If you want to get better at the work you need to build projects that challenge you and be honest about your results. How can your results improve? Where did your results succeed? You should also find at least one person with experience that’ll give you feedback on your projects.

topLevelComment.text: HTML is "hate-mail" with the vowels taken out.  And if it's so universal, why can't I watch my favorite videos on YouTube without it?  I used to be able to watch a lot of interesting things.  But no more.   YouTube's executives, who insist my poor (but functioning) computer has to have HTML5 without telling me what it is or how to get it, should have a serious curse placed on them.  Or do they just get a kickback from the computer makers for selling me a more up-to-date computer?

topLevelComment.author: Mithcoriel
topLevelComment.text:
You forgot to edit some parts, where you  say the same sentence several times. Especially around 24:00 where you introduce the figcaption twice, and 26:30.

For someone like me who already knows HTML and just wanted to see what's new in HTML5, there are too many details for beginners.

For someone who's a complete beginner, the usage of CSS and Javascript is gonna be quite confusing. It's not very satisfying if you don't fully understand why adding a certain tag makes the background change. You're giving the newbies  the impression that <div class="green"> is all it takes to make a green background, when really that's 90% CSS and only a small part of it is using the style in the HTML.

topLevelComment.author: Fausta Castaneda
topLevelComment.text: Why does everyone who "teaches" HTML make the same mistake of saying that an id can only be used once in a page????? The id NAME can only be used once, but you can use ID as many times as you want on any page.

replies.author: D. L.
replies.text: @Unique Everywhere I had the same question. Thanks for the awesome explanation!!👍

replies.author: Unique Everywhere
replies.text:
@Ananias Danda 
You can think of the CLASS as a type of item and ID as a specific item.

For example, if you have some buttons that control a video on a page, all of the control buttons might have a CLASS of "media_button", while the button that plays the video might have an ID of "play".

We could use the CLASS if we want to give all media buttons a 3D effect.  We could use the ID if we wanted to show a specific button as pressed.

replies.author: Unique Everywhere
replies.text: He clarified at 9:40 that only one element should have that specific ID.  At first, though, it did sound like it was the attribute that had to be unique, rather than the value.

replies.author: Ahmed Elselly
Ramon Cristancho
replies.text: Wait... Tell me if I'm wrong, in my research learning HTML a time ago, the ID attr can be used only in specific element because if you are working with JS you can't call the ID if they are being used by a several elements, let's say an ID for a input called "first_name" you can't use that same ID with another input. That's why they are ID, with the name attr that doesn't happen, if you call ID from JS they bring you a single data, if you call name the bring you a array of data. For me using two or more ID in one page, always gave me error

topLevelComment.author: Ghrib Omar
topLevelComment.text: But I wanna know something, If we have tamplates ready, and with html we make statiques websites, why do we learn html? we just need to use wix or wordpress to make them without the need to learning the html language, can anyone explain it to me? I hope I explained my self well

replies.author: Fausta Castaneda
replies.text: Because not everyone wants to have the same site as everyone else. If you think you can just use the same template that everyone else is using and you have no problem with it, then yes you don't need HTML.

topLevelComment.author: Clan of the Ducks
topLevelComment.text:
I know it's nitpicking. But extension != filetype.

Sure in Windows you can presume that an .exe is an exe. But I could properly put an image in it and an image viewer on Linux would show it perfectly whilst Windows would have an field day with it.
The defining of an html document purely takes place in the document itself by defining the doctype.

topLevelComment.author: Gary
topLevelComment.text: Are there any benefits of using section/article/main/nav/article tags instead of divs?  Is it for SEO to help identify the content, or do browsers render these differently in any way?

replies.author: Fausta Castaneda
replies.text: It's for semantics. Screen readers wouldn't know that for example your header is a header if you just use div. Or any other section etc. That plus the most used HTML class and div names were used to create the new tags. Which also make sense that a header would have a "header" tag, a sidebar a "sidebar" tag, etc
